Answer: If any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic, is magic a technology?More like magic is science. To call it a science is a more accurate term.Fire to us is something we take for granted and something people (some more than others) know how fire works.Fire to us is science.But in ancient times fire was viewed as something almost supernatural. That the ancient Greek saw as something given by the gods.And I'm pretty sure those first humans when they saw fire, to them fire was something that was beyond their comprehension.A few decades ago a cellphone would've looked likeIf any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic, is magic a technology?More like magic is science. To call it a science is a more accurate term.Fire to us is something we take for granted and something people (some more than others) know how fire works.Fire to us is science.But in ancient times fire was viewed as something almost supernatural. That the ancient Greek saw as something given by the gods.And I'm pretty sure those first humans when they saw fire, to them fire was something that was beyond their comprehension.A few decades ago a cellphone would've looked like alien technology. Almost magical.But now it's science.People (some more than others) know exactly how a cellphone works.Now we are scratching at Quantum Mechanics.Quantum Mechanics has the potential to allow us to do things that are now classified as magic or fiction.If we ever master Quantum Mechanics we'll be able to make things like teleportation, holographic projection, faster than light travel and communication, anti-gravity, and many more things day to day tools.Now… Will we ever be able to say a few words and things simply happen?Obviously not.But maybe. Just maybe, we'll be able to make our brains consciously operate at frequencies that lore around the world says are necessary to access what now is seen as supernatural abilities.That or we might be able to create a piece of technology that reads human thoughts, and can translate those thoughts into a kind of Matter-Energy manipulation.Where we can through those devices sense the energy in us and those things around us. And by extending our mind into it we can make objects move or/and change their shape/state.And maybe if and when that technology is made common use, people will then never understand how such things were ever viewed as supernatural or magical.Those in the future looking back at us will laugh at our own naive and gullible understanding of the world.

Answer: Magic doesn’t exist. Magical effects do - and are practised by entertainers all over the world, also by some charlatans who claim to have real magical powers (psychic surgeons, mediums, a certain spoon-bending oil-divining showman, etc.) but cannot prove them unless they control all the conditions of the test.Some magical entertainers do use technology - stage illusionists for example, rely wholly upon carefully designed mechanical props. However, that is magic USING technology, not BECOMING technology.Reversing the premise simply doesn’t work.

Answer: As an old 1st Cavalry trooper, I really like where your question is coming from. Bringing back the Horse would make the shades of every Cavalry man smile from whatever paradise they now exist in. Heaven, Valhalla the Elysian fields, you name it, They would love it! All Horse Warriors go to their reward, you know.Now to practicalities. What will we use? Kevlar. Relatively light and incredibly effective. It's used on modern warships in place of the wrought iron, Harvey Steel or Krupp cemented Armor of the past. Vests of some sort could be fashioned for man and horse with pockets to carry KevlarAs an old 1st Cavalry trooper, I really like where your question is coming from. Bringing back the Horse would make the shades of every Cavalry man smile from whatever paradise they now exist in. Heaven, Valhalla the Elysian fields, you name it, They would love it! All Horse Warriors go to their reward, you know.Now to practicalities. What will we use? Kevlar. Relatively light and incredibly effective. It's used on modern warships in place of the wrought iron, Harvey Steel or Krupp cemented Armor of the past. Vests of some sort could be fashioned for man and horse with pockets to carry Kevlar plates. This is how a flak jacket is designed. Like knights armor, it would be thicker i.e. more Kevlar plates in front than back. The Rider could be protected. The Horse is the problem.You could swaddle the front and sides of a horse in Kevlar plates just as the future draft horses the knights used were protected. But there are three insurmountable problems.Primus, the legs. Horses are big but have relatively thin legs. Even big steeds like Percherons, Shires and Clydesdales. The mounts of the knights of France, England and Scotland respectively. How do you armor the legs? You cant.Secundas, logistics. Horses, especially draft horses eat a lot of grain and hay. You grow it in , say Nebraska and have to get it to wherever the horses are. It's all the same, whether it's grain and hay or oil and gasoline. Logistics are a bear.Tertius, size. Once again horses are big. And because they are, they are targets. Trust me, every horse on a modern battlefield would draw a maelstrom of fire.So, regretfully. We can't do it. But it was fun to try. Let's hear it for the Horse. The Horse has made us what we are. Fascinating new discoveries in genetics and Archaeology have shown us that a primal people of the steppes first tamed the horse. In doing so they went from wandering Hunter gatherers to the Lords of the World. In fact, these first horseman created the first Empires, long ago in the mists of pre history and generations before the Sumerians first started to farm the fertile Crescent. Their partnership with horses enabled them to dominate. And not just in battle. These Horse Lords are the Ancestors of most Eurasian people. Not wanting to beat a dead horse, I bid you good bye.

One of the problems is the locking up of diagnostic information so that the tractor owner or local mechanic cannot diagnose a root cause of a problem. This means that a tractor owner has to go to an authorised dealer to get service at inflated prices and at the whim of the dealer. Farmers are fighting back and buying older tractors or keeping the older ones they have.

This invention could remove language barriers and make travelling - and doing business with other cultures – much easier. With these earbuds, someone could be standing in front of you speaking French, and the earbuds will feed you the English translation. The earbuds can translate 40 different languages!

Answer: Well, let’s think about it for a bit.What kind of technologies have been invented in the last century?We have things like radar, and microwave, and the internet, and satellites and computer chips, and nuclear power, and canned food, and drones, and aviation technology, and GPS, and infant formula, and indexing of websites for search engines, and bar codes, and touch screens, and vaccines, and windpower, and the accelerometer, and fire resistant clothing, and aerodynamic trucks, airbags, miniature cameras that fit in a webcam or cellphone, weather forecasting, and submarines, cellular technologWell, let’s think about it for a bit.What kind of technologies have been invented in the last century?We have things like radar, and microwave, and the internet, and satellites and computer chips, and nuclear power, and canned food, and drones, and aviation technology, and GPS, and infant formula, and indexing of websites for search engines, and bar codes, and touch screens, and vaccines, and windpower, and the accelerometer, and fire resistant clothing, and aerodynamic trucks, airbags, miniature cameras that fit in a webcam or cellphone, weather forecasting, and submarines, cellular technology and networks, RAM memory, hard disk drives, liquid-crystal displays, lithium batteries, so on.But all that kind of stuff was developed by having governments getting involved, funding research and science and so on.Which, as we all know, is a really inefficient method, it pretty much doesn’t work.Instead of this inefficient method that clearly doesn’t work, of having governments take part in research and development, we now have a much better strategy for innovation:Random guys in their garage!As we all know, that’s where all the true innovation comes from, random middle class dudes, who have ideas, and then do a startup in their garage.Either that, or huge corporations who invest in ways to extend their patents.So now, we have much more groundbreaking innovation.We have things like Amazon, who patented and made a fortune off one-click buying, the truly revolutionary idea of not making people click more than needed.Do you really think that government could have ever come up with a brilliant idea like that, huh?

Answer: The lame answer, but most accurate one, is probably the internal combustion engine. It’s the main reason I’m not a farmer or peasant, like all of my ancestors probably were until the early 1900s. Every part of the chain that feeds me, from the planting, reaping, processing, and delivery, is dependent upon something that runs on an internal combustion engine.As far as technology that I actually lived without at some point, the internet is the obvious choice. I rarely watch TV. I haven’t really watched much TV since I was a teenager. I prefer to be online. Watching a 30-minute TV show usually boThe lame answer, but most accurate one, is probably the internal combustion engine. It’s the main reason I’m not a farmer or peasant, like all of my ancestors probably were until the early 1900s. Every part of the chain that feeds me, from the planting, reaping, processing, and delivery, is dependent upon something that runs on an internal combustion engine.As far as technology that I actually lived without at some point, the internet is the obvious choice. I rarely watch TV. I haven’t really watched much TV since I was a teenager. I prefer to be online. Watching a 30-minute TV show usually bores me, but being online for hours on end seems like fun to me. Before Quora, I would spend those hours online playing video games.I’ve been online in some form or another since the mid 1990s. I check the internet first thing in the morning (Quora notifications), and last thing before I go to sleep (also Quora notifications). I use it to fill my leisure time. I use it at work… I use Google Classroom and youtube a lot in my class. I’d estimate that I spend more time on my laptop than I spend doing anything else any given day, including sleeping.
